question: With whom does the Emperor of Morocco correspond in the narrative's depiction of diplomatic or political exchanges?
gold_answer: The Emperor of Morocco corresponds with Mr. Hay.
llm_answer: The context mentions only that “Mr. Hay's correspondence with this Court on the Slave-trade” took place; no other named correspondents of the Emperor appear in the passages provided.

context.text: Monsieur Benou, in his "Description Geographique de l'Empire de Maroc" says Morocco "comprend une superficie d'environ 5,775 myriametres carres, un peu plus grande, par consequant, que celle de la France, qui equivaut a 5,300." This then is the available and immediate territory of Morocco, not comprising distant dependencies, where the Shereefs exercise a precarious or nominal sovereignty. Previously to particularizing the population of Morocco, I shall take the liberty of introducing some general observations on the whole of the inhabitants of North Africa, and the manner in which this country was successively peopled and conquered. Greek and Roman classics contain only meagre and confused notions of the aborigines of North Africa, although they have left us a mass of details on the Punic wars, and the struggles which ensued between the Romans and the ancient Libyans, before the domination of the Latin Republic could be firmly established. Herodotus cites the names of a number of people who inhabited North Africa, mostly confining himself to repeat the fables or the more interesting facts, of which they were the object. The nomenclature of Strabo is neither so extensive, nor does it contain more precise or correct information. He mentions the celebrated oasis of Ammonium and the nation of the Nasamones. Farther west, behind Carthage and the Numidians, he also notices

[Illustration] TRAVELS IN MOROCCO, BY THE LATE JAMES RICHARDSON, AUTHOR OF "A MISSION TO CENTRAL AFRICA," "TRAVELS IN THE DESERT OF SAHARA," &C. EDITED BY HIS WIDOW. [Illustration] IN TWO VOLUMES. VOL. II. CONTENTS OF THE SECOND VOLUME. CHAPTER I. The Mogador Jewesses.--Disputes between the Jew and the Moor.--Melancholy Scenes.--The Jews of the Atlas.--Their Religion.--Beautiful Women.--The Four Wives.--Statues discovered.--Discrepancy of age of married people.-- Young and frail fair ones.--Superstition respecting Salt.--White Brandy.--Ludicrous Anecdote. CHAPTER II. The Maroquine dynasties.--Family of the Shereefian Monarchs.--Personal appearances and character of Muley Abd Errahman.--Refutation of the charge of human sacrifices against the Moorish Princes.--Genealogy of the reigning dynasty of Morocco.--The tyraufc Yezeed, (half Irish).--Muley Suleiman, the "The Shereeff of

white and other livelier colours. However, men get used to their misery, and hug their chains. The Jews, at times, though but very rarely, avail themselves of their privilege of four wives granted them in Mahometan countries, and a nice mess they make of it. I knew a Jew of this description in Tunis. He was a lively, jocose fellow, with a libidinous countenance, singing always some catch of a song. He was a silk-mercer, and pretty well off. His house was small, and besides a common _salle-a-manger_, divided into four compartments for his four wives, each defending her room with the ferocity of a tigress. Two of them were of his own age, about fifty, and two not more than twenty. The two elder ones, I was told by his neighbours, were entirely abandoned by the husband, and the two younger ones were always bickering and quarrelling, as to which of them should have the greater favour of their common tyrant; the house a scene of tumult, disorder and indecency. Amongst the whole of the wives, there was only one child, a boy, of course an immense pet, a little surly wretch; his growth smothered, his health nearly ruined, by the overattentions of the four women, whom he kicked and pelted when out of humour. This little imp was the fit type, or interpretation

Zereids) were usurpers of the former conquerors; their dynasty terminated in 1070. 4th. Moravedi (or Marabouteen,) that is to say, Marabouts, [2] who rose into consequence about 1050, and their first prince was Aberbekr Omer El Lamethounx, a native of Sous. Their dynasty terminated in 1149. 5th. The Almohades. These are supposed to be sprung from the Berber tribes. They conquered all North Western Morocco, and reigned about one hundred years, the dynasty terminated in 1269. 6th. The Merinites. These in 1250 subjugated the kingdoms of Fez and Morocco; and in 1480 their dynasty terminated with the Shereef. 7th. The Oatagi (or Ouatasi) [3] were a tribe of obscure origin. In their time, the Portuguese established themselves on the coast of Morocco; their dynasty ended in 1550. 8th. The Shereefs (Oulad Ali) of the present dynasty, whose founder was Hasein, have now occupied the Imperial throne more than three centuries. This family of Shereefs came from the neighbourhood of Medina in Arabia, and succeeded to the empire of Morocco by a series of usurpations. They are divided into two branches, the Sherfah Hoseinee, so named from the founder

the royal gardens. Whilst performing this feat before several attendants, the Sultan suddenly made his appearance in the midst of them. The minister seeing him, fell down in a fright and a fit. His Imperial Highness beckoned to the minister in such woful plight, to pacify himself, and put his cloak before his mouth to prevent any one from seeing him laugh at the minister, which he did most immoderately. Cohen, who is a quack, was once consulted on a case of the harem. Cohen pleaded ignorance, God had not given him the wit; he could do nothing for the patient of his Imperial Highness. This was very politic of Cohen, for another quack, a Moor, had just been consulted, and had had his head taken off, for not being successful in the remedies he prescribed. There would not be quite so much medicine administered among us, weak, cracky, crazy mortals, in this cold damp clime, if such an alternative was proposed to our practitioners. CHAPTER II. The Maroquine dynasties.--Family of the Shereefian Monarchs.--Personal appearances and character of Muley Abd Errahman.--Refutation of the charge of human sacrifices against the Moorish Princes.--Genealogy of the reigning dynasty of Morocco.--The tyraufc Yezeed, (half Irish).--Muley Suleiman, the "The Shereeff of

and happened in spite of him), has preserved the intact without, and quiet during the many years he has occupied the throne. His Moorish Majesty, who is advanced in life, is a man of middle stature. He has dark and expressive eyes, and, as already observed, is a mulatto of a fifth caste. Colour excites no prejudices either in the sovereign or in the subject. This Emperor is so simple in his habits and dress, that he can only be distinguished from his officers and governors of provinces by the _thall_, or parasol, the Shereefian emblem of royalty. The Emperor's son, when out on a military expedition, is also honoured by the presence of the Imperial parasol, which was found in Sidi Mohammed's tent at the Battle of Isly. Muley Abd Errahman is not given to excesses of any kind, (unless avarice is so considered), though his three harems of Fas, Miknas, and Morocco may be _stocked_, or more politely, adorned, with a thousand ladies or so, and the treasures of the empire are at his disposal. He is not a man of blood; [4] he rarely decapitates a minister or a governor, notwithstanding that he frequently confiscates their property, and sometimes imprisons them to discover their treasures, and drain them of their last farthing. The Emperor lives on good terms with the rest of his family. He has one son,

their treasures, and drain them of their last farthing. The Emperor lives on good terms with the rest of his family. He has one son, Governor of Fez (Sidi Mohammed), and another son, Governor of Rabat. The greater part of the royal family reside at Tafilett, the ancient country of the _Sherfah_, or Shereefs, and is still especially appropriated for their residence. Ali Bey reported as the information of his time, that there were at Tafilett no less than two thousand Shereefs, who all pretended to have a right to the throne of Morocco, and who, for that reasons enjoyed certain gratifications paid them by the reigning Sultan. He adds that, during an interregnum, many of them took up arms and threw the empire into anarchy. This state of things is happily past, and, as to the number of the Shereefs at Tafilett, all that we know is, there is a small fortified town, inhabited entirely by Shereefs, living in moderate, if not impoverished circumstances. The Shereefian Sultans of Morocco are not only the successors of the Arabian Sovereigns of Spain, but may justly dispute the Caliphat with the Osmanlis, or Turkish Sultans. Their right to be the chiefs of Islamism is better founded than the pretended Apostolic successors at Rome, who, in matters of religion, they in some points resemble. I introduce

Morocco.--The tyraufc Yezeed, (half Irish).--Muley Suleiman, the "The Shereeff of Shereefs."--Diplomatic relations of the Emperor of Morocco with European Powers.--Muley Ismael enamoured with the French Princess de Conti.--Rival diplomacy of France and England near the Maroquine Court.--Mr. Hay's correspondence with this Court on the Slave-trade.--Treaties between Great Britain and Morocco; how defective and requiring amendment.--Unwritten engagements. Morocco, an immense and unwieldly remnant of the monarchies formed by the Saracens, or first Arabian conquerors of Africa, has had a series of dynasties terminating in that of the Shereefs. 1st. The Edristees (pure Saracens,) their capital was Fez, founded by their great progenitor, Edrio. The dynasty began in A.D. 789, and continued to 908. 2nd. The Fatamites (also Saracens.) These conquered Egypt, and were the faction of or lineal descendants of the daughter of the Prophet, the beautiful pearl-like Fatima, succeeding to the above: this dynasty continued to 972. 3rd. The Zuheirites (Zeirities, or Zereids) were usurpers of the former conquerors; their dynasty terminated in 1070. 4th. Moravedi (or

a species of quasi-independence of the Imperial authority, but they usually attach themselves to certain Berber chieftains who protect them, and whose standards they follow. These are the only Jews in Mahometan countries of whom I have heard as bearing arms. They have, however, their own Sheiks, to whose jurisdiction all domestic matters are referred. They wear the same attire as the mountaineers, and are not distinguishable from them, they do not address the Moors by the term of respect and title "Sidi," but in the same way as the Moors and Arabs when they accost each other. They speak the Shelouh language. Mr. Davidson mentions some curious circumstances about these Jews, and of their having a city beyond the Atlas, where three or four thousand are living in perfect freedom, and cultivating the soil, which they have possessed since the time of Solomon. The probability is that Mr. Davidson's informant refers to the Jews of the Oasis of Sahara, where there certainly are some families of Jews living in comparative freedom and independence. As to the peculiarities of the religion of the Atlas Jews, they are said not to have the Pentateuch and the law in the same order as Jews generally. They are unacquainted with Ezra, or Christ; they did not go to Babylon at the captivity, but were dispersed over Africa at that period. They are a species of Caraaites, or Jewish Protestants. Shadai is the

captivity, but were dispersed over Africa at that period. They are a species of Caraaites, or Jewish Protestants. Shadai is the name which they apply to the Supreme Being, when speaking of him. Their written law begins by stating that the world was many thousand years old when the present race of men was formed, which, curiously enough, agrees with the researches of modern geology. The present race of men are the joint offspring of different and distinct human species. The deluge is not mentioned by them. God, it is said, appeared to Ishmael in a dream, and told him he must separate from Isaac, and go to the desert, where he would make him a great nation. There would ever after be enmity between the two races, as at this day there is the greatest animosity between the Jews and Mahometans. The great nucleus of these Shelouh Jews is in _Jebel Melge_, or the vast ridge of the Atlas capped with eternal snows; and they hold communications with the Jews of Ait Mousa, Frouga or Misfuva. They rarely descend to the plains or cities of the empire, and look upon the rest of the Jews of this country as heretics. Isolation thus begets enmity and mistrust, as in other cases. A few years ago, a number came to Mogador, and were not at all pleased with their visit, finding fault with

1. **Title**: Moroccan Trade and Geography
2. **Summary**: The text chunks discuss various aspects of Morocco, including its trade, geography, and culture. The country's ports, such as Mogador, Tangier, and Rabat, are major hubs for the export of goods like almonds, wool, and olive oil, and the import of goods like cotton, sugar, and tea. The chunks also describe the country's cities, like Fez, Taza, and Zawiat-Muley-Driss, and their historical and cultural significance. Additionally, the text mentions the influence of Grand Marabouts, or religious leaders, in the country's governance and the role of the Shereefs, or descendants of the Prophet Muhammad, in Moroccan society.
3. **Keywords**: Morocco, Trade, Geography, Marabouts, Shereefs

1. **Title**: Moroccan Cities and Geography
2. **Summary**: The text describes various cities and regions in Morocco, including their geography, history, and cultural significance. Cities such as Tetouan, Ceuta, Fez, and Rabat are mentioned, along with their architectural features, trade, and cultural practices. The text also touches on the country's history, including the influence of the Portuguese, Arabs, and Berbers. The regions of Morocco are described in terms of their natural resources, climate, and agricultural production. The text provides a comprehensive overview of Morocco's urban and rural landscapes, highlighting the country's rich cultural heritage and geographic diversity.
3. **Keywords**: Morocco, Cities, Geography, History, Culture

1. **Title**: Morocco and its Royal Cities
2. **Summary**: The text describes the state of Morocco and its royal cities, including Fez, Mequinez, and Tafilett, which are in decline. The country is ruled by the Shereefs, a dynasty of African blood, and the Sultan's presence is necessary to maintain allegiance in the north. The cities are characterized by their unique cultural and architectural features, such as the use of Dutch tiles and the production of wool and silk manufactures. The text also mentions the bombardment of Mogador by the French and the subsequent pillage and violence perpetrated by wild tribes. The British Consul and his wife narrowly escaped with their lives, and the city was left in a state of destruction.
3. **Keywords**: Morocco, Fez, Mequinez, Tafilett, Shereefs, Mogador

1. **Title**: Moroccan Jewish Community
2. **Summary**: The text discusses the Jewish community in Morocco, their history, culture, and treatment by the Moorish population. It highlights the struggles faced by the Jews, including oppression, violence, and forced conversion. The Atlas Jews are described as a unique group, living in the mountains and enjoying a degree of independence. The text also touches on the European Jewish community in Morocco and their interactions with the native population. The author notes the improvements in the treatment of Jews in recent times, but also acknowledges the ongoing challenges and prejudices they face.
3. **Keywords**: Moroccan Jews, Atlas Jews, Moorish Oppression, Jewish Culture, North African History

1. **Title**: Moroccan History and Demographics
2. **Summary**: The text chunks discuss the history and demographics of Morocco, including the Shereefian lineage, population estimates, and the distribution of various tribes and ethnic groups such as the Berbers, Arabs, and Amazirghs. The Shereefian lineage is outlined, with notable figures including Muley Ismail, Muley Abdullah, and Sidi Mohammed. The population estimates vary, with some sources suggesting the population is around 8-15 million, although these numbers are considered exaggerated. The text also touches on the geography and climate of Morocco, noting its similarity to Spain and Portugal, and the presence of the Atlas mountain range. The country's history and cultural influences are also discussed, including the presence of European refugees and the derivation of terms such as "Mauri" and "Saracini".
3. **Keywords**: Morocco, Shereefian, Berbers, Arabs, Demographics

1. **Title**: Morocco and its Empire
2. **Summary**: The text chunks discuss the history, geography, and culture of Morocco, including its rulers, such as Muley Abd Errahman and Muley Suleiman, and their impact on the empire. The chunks also touch on the country's relations with European powers, the treatment of slaves and women, and the daily life of Jews and Moors in Morocco. The empire's geography, climate, and natural resources are also described, highlighting the country's strategic location and diverse population. The text also explores the complexities of Moroccan society, including the role of the Shereefs and the influence of Islam.
3. **Keywords**: Morocco, Empire, Muley Abd Errahman, Shereefs, Islam

1. **Title**: Raccoon and Tea-Kettle Adventures
2. **Summary**: The text chunks revolve around the adventures of a raccoon and its interactions with a tea-kettle, which the raccoon believes to be alive. The raccoon is afraid of the tea-kettle and has had previous encounters with it, including getting its paw burned. The story also involves other characters, such as Toto and Bruin, who interact with the raccoon and the tea-kettle. Additionally, there are snippets of unrelated stories, including one about a boy named Chop-Chin and the Golden Dragon, and another about the Emperor of China. The overall tone is lighthearted and humorous, with a focus on the raccoon's misadventures.
3. **Keywords**: Raccoon, Tea-Kettle, Adventure, Fantasy, Humor

1. **Title**: Visiting the Lizard Lights
2. **Summary**: The text chunks describe a visit to the Lizard Lights, a lighthouse in Cornwall, where the visitors are given a tour by a young man who explains the machinery and instruments used to produce light and sound warnings for ships. Despite not fully understanding the technical explanations, the visitors are impressed by the complexity and scale of the operation and the young man's enthusiasm. The chunks also describe a visit to a home, where the hosts welcome the visitors with tea and hospitality, and share stories and mementos, including a candle used by an emperor to light a lighthouse. The overall tone is one of wonder, appreciation, and amusement at the people and places encountered.
3. **Keywords**: Lizard Lights, Cornwall, Lighthouse, Hospitality, Technology

1. **Title**: Jewish Identity and Nationality
2. **Summary**: The text chunks discuss the theme of Jewish identity, nationality, and the relationship between Jews and their host countries. The author explores the idea that Jews have maintained their sense of nationality and cultural identity despite centuries of persecution and dispersion. The text also touches on the concept of cosmopolitanism and how it relates to Jewish people, as well as the tension between Jewish identity and national identity. The author argues that a strong sense of nationality is essential for individual dignity and rectitude, and that Jews, like other nations, have a right to their own national consciousness. The text also critiques anti-Semitic attitudes and stereotypes, highlighting the dangers of prejudice and the importance of understanding and empathy.
3. **Keywords**: Jewish Identity, Nationality, Cosmopolitanism, Anti-Semitism, Cultural Heritage

1. **Title**: Exploring Cornwall's Landscapes
2. **Summary**: The text chunks describe the author's experiences and observations while traveling through Cornwall, a region in England. The author recounts their encounters with the local landscape, including the Lizard Peninsula, Land's End, and the Logan Rock. They also interact with the local people, visit shops, and experience the region's unique weather patterns, including a intense storm. The author reflects on the importance of mindset in traveling and the value of simplicity in exploration. The text also touches on the region's history, folklore, and natural beauty, showcasing the author's appreciation for the area's distinctive character.
3. **Keywords**: Cornwall, Travel, Landscape, Nature, Exploration
